conclusion: Analyze forces and use equilibrium conditions to find electric field strength E.
The forces acting on the ball are gravitational force, electric force, and tension force.
Gravitational force acts vertically downward with magnitude F_g = mg.
Electric force acts horizontally to the right with magnitude F_e = qE.
Tension force acts along the string at an angle θ from the vertical.
Resolve tension force into vertical component T_y = T cosθ and horizontal component T_x = T sinθ.
Apply equilibrium condition: vertical component of tension balances gravitational force T_y = mg.
Substitute T_y = T cosθ into equilibrium condition: T cosθ = mg.
Apply equilibrium condition: horizontal component of tension balances electric force T_x = qE.
Substitute T_x = T sinθ into equilibrium condition: T sinθ = qE.
Solve for T from T cosθ = mg: T = mg/cosθ.
Substitute T = mg/cosθ into T sinθ = qE: mg/cosθ sinθ = qE.
Simplify mg sinθ/cosθ = qE using tanθ = sinθ/cosθ: mg tanθ = qE.
Solve for E: E = mg tanθ/q.
Final answer: Electric field strength E = mg tanθ/q.
